Class ec.ezlib.base.DoubleSugar 

java.lang.Object
   |
   +----ec.ezlib.base.DoubleSugar
public class DoubleSugar
extends Object
A sweetener defining extra messages that may be e-sent to a floating point number.

OTHER_TYPE

acos(double)
add(double, double)
approxDivide(double, double)
Always gives back a double This corresponds to the Java floating-point "/" operator and the EZ "/" operator.

 public static final Class OTHER_TYPE

add

subtract

                               double arg)

abs 
 public static Double abs(double num)
approxDivide 
 public static Double approxDivide(double rec,
                                   double arg)
Always gives back a double This corresponds to the Java floating-point "/" operator and the EZ "/" operator.

truncDivide 
 public static long truncDivide(double rec,
                                double arg)
Always gives an integer resulting from rounding towards zero, ie, truncating. This corresponds to the Java integer "/" operator.

remainder 
 public static Double remainder(double rec,
                                double arg)
Remainder from truncDivide operation. 

      (a truncDivide b)*b + (a remainder b) == a
      [ 5, 3]: ( 1* 3) +  2 ==  5
      [ 5,-3]: (-1*-3) +  2 ==  5
      [-5, 3]: (-1* 3) + -2 == -5
      [-5,-3]: ( 1*-3) + -2 == -5

Therefore, if the result is non-zero, the sign of the result must be the same as the sign of a. This corresponds to the Java and EZ "%" operator.

floorDivide 
 public static BigInteger floorDivide(double rec,
                                      double arg)
Always gives an integer, resulting from rounding towards negative infinity, ie, flooring. This corresponds to the EZ "//" operator.

mod 
 public static Double mod(double rec,
                          double arg)
Remainder from the floorDivide operation. 

     (a floorDivide b)*b + (a modulo b) == a
      [ 5, 3]: ( 1* 3) +  2 ==  5
      [ 5,-3]: (-2*-3) + -1 ==  5
      [-5, 3]: (-2* 3) +  1 == -5
      [-5,-3]: ( 1*-3) + -2 == -5

Therefore, if the result is non-zero, the sign of the result must be the same as the sign of b, and so the result ranges from 0 inclusive to b exclusive. This corresponds to the EZ "%%" operator. When b >= 0, it also corresponds to Java's BigInteger.mod().

 public static Double random(double rec)
A number randomly chosen between 0 and this number. Only as good as Math.random(), which it uses.
